rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Kurzman is an AWESOME sociology professor. The course material doesn't exactly lend itself to fascination, but Kurzman is clear and explains exactly what you need to know. The exams aren't bad as long as you listen to his instructions and they are open book so be sure to take notes verbatim. He is great.

I guess he hasn't taught this in a few years, but he must've gotten better because he is AMAZING. Generally this would be a super boring course, but Kurzman makes it simple, clear and to the point. He grades kind of hard, but it willing to work with you. Learned so much, which I needed as a soci major.

I loved this class. The subject matter can seem obscure at times (Foucault, Haraway, etc) but Kurzman's lectures are engaging and clear. However, the TA's were painfully out of sync with the material. As long as you do all the work, an A is guaranteed. Definitely worth it.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Interesting guy, but I found the class boring and a lot of petty work.  The service learning compenent made the class interesting, but added greatly to the time I put into it.  Definitely need to keep up on the reading and be very involved in class.  Our class was too big to have good projects/teach class/discuss as we were supposed to.
Do the readings and you're ok! Very interesting class and he's a cool guy.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: SHE IS GREAT!! I absolutely loved her class. The readings are attention grabbing. There are a lot but its nothing that cant be done. The class is worth it I promise. Taking her class has definitely made me more aware of the issues in our society. As long as you do the work you will do fine in the class. One of the best professors I have had so far!

Sherryl is absolutely fantastic. She is so intelligent and you will learn so incredibly much about WMST. This class should be required for all students at UNC. Expect a good amount of reading but nothing ridiculous. Only a midterm and final as far as tests go. Reflection papers once a week and quizzes once a week (not hard I promise) Take it!

Sherryl is fantastic!! She is one of the most enlightening people I've ever met and one of the best professors. Must take. There is a good amount of reading, but it is all worth it. Reflection papers due on Tues and quizzes on Thurs. All easy As. Exam questions given in advance.  Must email to enroll. DO IT

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Very hard to understand and his lectures are extremely boring. Tests are definitely not easy A's - there are always random questions that are almost impossible to answer. There is no homework although probably do the readings or else you will not be able to answer many test questions.

His lectures are mega-boring, and put me to sleep almost every time. The tests are straight forward from the lecture power points, and he is a pretty easy grader. Not a hard professor, decently easy class.

This class requires very little work; however, the tests are a little more difficult than expected with a lot of questions drawn from material not in lecture. Not necessarily an easy A.  Lectures are kind of boring, though the information is fairly interesting. Curves the class well.
Awesome class/professor! prof. nielsen is really nice and as long as you do the reading and come to class it's not too difficult. interesting too
Wonderful professor.  Soft-spoken, but very kind and interested in Sociology and the success of his students.  He clearly communicates his expectations, and his lectures are exceptionally organized.
Very nice and accessible. Works to help students learn material, even meet after class. Easy grader. Knows/teaches lots of interesting obscure stuff. His voice might make you sleepy though!

Nielsen is a wonderful teacher. He may not be as vibrant as others, but he is very clear (and provides excellent notes), and shows a lot of interest in his subject and in his students. Great beard too. He's a sweet guy and has a quirky accent. I'd recommend taking his classes.

Dr Nielsen is a really great teacher. His preparation is impeccable.  Many will not appreciate his bone dry European humor, given taht this is UNC and many students are from the countryside of North Carolina. He is also a very generous grader.
This class was horribly boring. And we had to do projects to present to the class--they were graded VERY subjectively. I would not recommend taking this class, even though it's pretty easy.
Prof Nielsen bored me out of my mind. I was originally very interested in sociology, but after taking this class, I will not take another sociology class.

You get half credit for just showing up and taking a quiz. And the questions are really easy. The only assignment is to fill out your family tree. The reading is pretty easy and you don't even really need to read it because the midterm and final are so easy and 95% taken from the notes he goes over in class.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He taught a great first year seminar on the "McDonaldization of Society".  He's passionate about teaching, sociology, and helping students understand the material.
ok. not a hard grader and a decent teacher, but kind of a flake. relies heavily on jargon, ideology and intellectual trends.
No Comments
No Comments
Are you people smoking crack? Aldfrich was one of, if not THE, best professors I had a Carolina.
No Comments
Although not an action packed class, he really cares about the topics and wants the students to be interested and involved.  There's plenty of work, but if you do it, you'll get a decent grade.
Do not take him for anything.
a total bore!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Class is basically a student presenting homework, which is an extremely long and technical research paper. A majority of the grade is the midterm and final, both of which are extremely difficult. He makes the answer choices all the same, and manages to have grammatical errors everywhere. This was harder than MATH 231 or CHEM 102. I do not recommend

He tries ot make the class interesting but by the end of the semester I got so sick of hearing about his Princeton days + ivy league rankings. I had to restrain myself from saying "go and teach at Princeton, then!...but I didn't

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: On the first day Tyson will seem very intimidating. She warms up to her students and really cares about them learning as much as possible. You have to do the reading, which is sometimes a lot, but there is no final and the whole grade is based off of the paper you work on throughout the semester in groups. I loved this class!

Professor Tyson was by far the most passionate prof. I had my freshman year. Her class was difficult and she expected a lot out of her freshman but she is really not as scary as she seems and cares about her students and their success.

This class was very engaging and discussion-based. The reading was required, but interesting. Tyson is brilliant. However, she is a bit inaccessible. You have to put in quite a bit of effort to build any sort of relationship. Also, she will not respond to emails that she does not think are important, which is very frustrating and a bit rude.

Professor Tyson is really great. At first, she is extremely intimidating but as the semester goes on she is very friendly and works well with the students. She genuinely cares about improving students writing and works with you to improve. The class material is very interesting but be sure to do the reading ahead of time.

Her first year seminar on equality of educational opportunity is really interesting with a light workload at first that steadily increases to a HUGE workload by the end of the semester. Professor Tyson is pretty intimidating, but incredibly brilliant and helpful if you just seek her out yourself. Always do the readings and come prepared to talk.

She seems super scary on the first day, but she eventually warms up. Definitely go to every class and take all the quizzes - they are fine if you do the readings and have an opinion. Bad with email and ignores what she doesn't want to deal with. See the TA for help with the final paper, and things surprisingly work out! Was happy with my grade.

She's a really tough teacher, but not so bad once you get to know her. Go to the quizzes, study and do the readings and you will be fine. She's pretty engaging though the intensity wears out by the end of the semester. The final is super short and easy because of the paper.

Weekly quizzes graded 0, 5 or 10.  She's very picky with the answers she accepts so most people get fives. There's also a 15 page paper at the end and an apples requirement.Its not an easy class but its worth the work. She's very passionate and knows her stuff. She's very good at engaging her students.She seems intimidating, but shes actually nice.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Although readings are assigned, you don't have much daily homework. The real problem with the class is his lack of communication when it comes to assignments and the boring lectures. There are also few grading opportunities.  Participation is mandatory in the discussion session of the class, so get ready to talk or your grade will suffer.
Participating in the discussions matters a lot in your grade. I attended classes and paid attention, but I didn't raise my hand to participate. This screwed my grade over.

Here's the thing about Professor Perrin. He was respectful of different viewpoints, expected discussion, and gave interesting lectures. However, he grades based on the department standard of an average of B-. So you have to go above and beyond on assignments and tests by answering more than he asked for to get an A. But once you do, it's not hard.
Unless  you want to be a soci major, avoid at all costs.

Prof. Perrin is very passionate about what he does and he really understands college students. He brought his children to class on several occasions. He finds innovative ways to make material more applicable and memorable.
Avoid him at all costs. Awful and sarcastic about helping his students. Grades according to his opinion. His  open note tests are set up to make you fail

Though midterm&final were open booknote, grading was unfair. Doesn't like opinions that conflict with his&won't give any credit for them. Class is so boring, wanted to sleep through it each time. Gives grade based on participation, yet never writes down who speaks so must be an arbitrary number to him. Only few grades, so no room for mistakes.

Professor Perrin clearly has a passion for sociology, and does a pretty good job making it interesting.  However, the lectures can get pretty long and there are only about 4 important grades in the semester, so if you bomb one you're in trouble.

I had him for a FYS and he wasn't a good teacher. He strongly played favorites and was forceful with his opinions. If you disagreed with him, he would not show much respect for you. He didn't answer questions well and cut me off when I would ask them. He also graded unfairly and wouldn't justify grades I received when I talked to him. Bad guy.

Had this guy for a theory class, he didn't bother to do any teaching, making the students lecture. He would periodically interrupt to cut the presenter down and show how 'smart' he is. Overall kind of creepy, stay away!

The worst part about this class was that he had a mandatory discussion grade.  You are graded on how much to talk in class, which is ridiculous.  He was an ok teacher, very enthusiastic; however, the discussion part was hideous.

Professor Perrin is one of the best teachers I have ever had.  I had him for a FYS, and I have no doubt that it will always be at the top of the list of my favorite classes.  Lots of discussion; a little bit of reading; a lots of support and a friendly atmosphere.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Prof. Andrews is one of the kindest professors at UNC. His lectures can be a little boring, but the class is pretty easy and I love him. You do a sort of case study on a social movement of your choosing and write a few papers throughout. They're easy to get an A though. I turned one in 4 hrs late and got a 95%. He's a great mentor, too
Interesting.
Andy gets hotness points for his beard.
great prof.  he directed the seminar very well and the readings made the discussions very interesting.   he is also a great cook

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: He funny, and tries to engage his students. He expects you to be ready for a college level workload, but is always there to help. Actually cares about his students.
Doesn't return any graded assignments. No rubrics or assignment descriptions so you are left to figure things out by yourself! Would never recommend his class.

Professor Mouw rocks! He's very relatable and wants everybody to succeed. Although the class required a fair bit of reading, all of it was enjoyable and interesting and the follow-up discussions were extremely insightful and deep.
Such a great guy! He's so nice and he really knows what he's talking about. The class is pretty easy and he doesn't overload you with work. I definitely recommend taking this or any of his classes!
Ted is the best! Take his class you will not regret it!

If you get a chance to take his class then do.  I took a freshman seminar with him and it was my best class I've had yet.  Just do the short assignments before each class and you will do well.  Ted Mouw is the man!
Ummmm.... GREAT TEACHER...still talk to him after course 2 years later. Hilarious, and enjoys what he does! Do your self a favor, and TAKE HIM! You want regret IT!

You know the little box you can check on the end of course evaluations that say "fully deserving of a teaching award"?  This is the only professor where I felt the need to check it.  Funny, interesting, overall a great guy.  Just do the daily assignments (easy) and attend class and you'll get an A.  I wish I could have a class with him every term.

I took his class twice its that awesome, got A's both times  (Social Strat and Economy and Society)both early morning classes, however he is a very funny guy and kept class fun- expect discussion it is part of the grade-always do the homework because its graded and will be apart of discussion as well as on the tests- EASY A if all work is done!
No Comments
Great Teacher!!
This was the best class I have ever taken at UNC!!!  He is a wonderful professor and a really nice guy!
He is AWESOME!!!! There's alot of readings but the class is fairly easy and very interesting! A+++

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Great Professor, hopefully I'll be able to take another class with him before I leave Carolina!

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: She is an amazing professor! There are readings (you have to do since there are in class assignments) and write-ups each week, but they lead to the term paper (7-8 pages). Overall, the class is not too much work and is very interesting. Prof. is very interested in the subject and enthusiastic! Midterm and final prompts are given beforehand.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Ms. Yang really cares for her students. I'm really bad at math, but she was always there to help me when I needed it. I failed my first test, but she was really understanding and helpful and went over the test with me to go over my mistakes. She's a good teacher and her lectures are clear-cut.

Caroline is the best math teacher that I have ever had. She is more than willing to meet with you one-on-one and help you understand all material fully. All of the material is explained fully in class though so as long as you pay attention, it is relatively easy to understand. Take all notes in class and go to class and you will do well.

Came into this class as a student that struggled in math and this class was no different. She's a tough grader and wants things done in a specific way and will take off points. Class is mostly examples that don't really apply to the tests and the homework is a lot easier than the test questions. Final was different than review and weird wording.
The class is fairly easy but she is a VERY tough grader. She wants answers in a specific format and if you forget anything she will most likely mark points off.

rmp.university: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
comments: Professor Cai is really nice, but struggles with his English and explaining concepts. I got an A, but I felt confused 99% of the time.

Professor Cai is skilled when discussing or using data analysis software. What he could stand to improve from is articulating concepts and relating them back to the class example. There were lots of times someone asked a question and he would answer in a detailed and unspecific way you wouldn't remember what the original question was. Read the book

The course is basically the textbook. Some questions were literally copied from it. HIs accent makes it hard to understand what he is trying to say occasionally. Despite all this, he is very knowledgeable in his field, ties the subject matter to his background well, and is very fair.
